III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that each
employee and volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or
more hours per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free
from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current verification.
Nine of seventeen new hire employee files reviewed did not have documentation
that the TB test was read prior to the date of employment. THIS IS A REPEAT
VIOLATION from the Renewal Inspection Report, 3/6/2019 with an approved
CAP on 4/12/2019.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
does not have youth that fall under ISEP reporting requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract/Policy violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility does not contract with DHHS.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 161: Indicate specific behavior. Just stating that a resident was a threat to others is
not enough. Indicate how they are a threat to others.
R 128: The facility was directed to ensure that the same documentation (training list)
of training hours is found in each file. Some of the files had different documentation
for training.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
1

The facility was encouraged to develop an electronic record keeping system for all of
the documentation they are required to have.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The facility has submitted four acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first CAP, dated 10/10/2019, was submitted in response to special investigation
report 2019C0207029, dated 9/30/2019. The facility was cited for a violation of R. 124
as the evidence supported that allegation that the resident had unauthorized and
inappropriate communication with friends. The facility was also cited for a violation of
R. 126 because there was a lack of sufficient supervision of the resident during
visitation. There has been no further evidence that these violation have occurred
again, suggesting that the facility is complying with their CAP.
The second CAP, dated 10/28/2019, was submitted in response to special
investigation report 2019C0207031, dated 10/14/2019. The facility was cited for a
violation of R 128 when it was discovered that the staff involved in a restraint that did
not follow policy had not received the required restraint training. There has been no
further evidence that these violations have occurred again, suggesting that the facility
is complying with their CAP.
The third CAP, dated 4/7/2020, was submitted in response to special investigation
report 2020C0207011, dated 3/30/2020. The facility was cited for a violation of R. 163
as the evidence supported that the resident was placed in a room seclusion without
being a harm to himself or others. There has been no further evidence that these
violations have occurred again, suggesting that the facility is complying with their
CAP.
The fourth CAP, dated 4/9/2019, was in response to the last Renewal Inspection
Report, dated 4/11/2019. There is one repeat violation in this report when compared
to the 2019 Renewal report. This single repeat violation involves R 114 as noted
above.
Interviews were conducted and the resident indicated feeling safe and cared for at the
facility. The staff report a desire to provide best practice and believes he is supported
by the administration. The administration also indicated a desire to provide best
practice and was able to identify the issues that involved the repeat violation.
2

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. The facility has submitted an acceptable corrective action plan;
therefore, it is recommended that the facility continue on their regular license.
